subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)
msgSnippet: I believe that the decay of the wh or hw sound if you prefer has been taking place for over a century or maybe two.  It is not easy to hear the difference
messageBody:
I believe that the decay of the "wh" or "hw" sound if you prefer has
been taking place for over a century or maybe two. It is not easy to
hear the difference in speech unless one happens to be listening
closely. I believe those whose job it is to do so have mapped where the
sound is still used in the U.S. and where it isn't. My understanding is
that approximately 20% of the population still uses the sound. I
suspect younger speakers may be more likely to ignore the sound.

For those who have never used it, it seems superfluous as you indicate.
However, for those of us who do use it, deleting it from QS, would make
the alphabet less accurate in its transcription of our speech. We would
resent that as much as anyone else would if someone suggested the
deletion of a phoneme which they happen to be fond of because it appears
in their idiolect. For example, if we decided that English should no
longer use the "awe" sound, this would annoy many people across the
country. Nevertheless, I believe Canadians are quite content to avoid
its use altogether. An example: "cot" and "caught" are pronounced the
same. Sure seems peculiar to me, but it doesn't keep me from
understanding them.

I counsel not throwing symbols out just because you don't happen to use
that particular sound. Somewhere, there are others who do. That is why
I have no problem with the inclusion of the "ch" as in Scottish "loch"
even though I don't use it. It hurts nothing for it to remain in QS as
there is no compulsion for me to use it.

One last point: if I write with the "wh" sound, you will notice it and
hear something of my accent, which i find one of the attractive things
about QS. I corresponded with a New Zealander in QS 25 years ago, and I
could hear his accent in his writing. And it didn't keep me from
understanding him at all.

Paige Gabhart

kyudosha wrote:

>>Letter 20 is also unused by Americans, but serves as a nice
>>abbreviation for "what". In fact, I would be inclined to say that
>>both 20 AND 34 could be stricken from the alphabet for all english
>>speakers and Readscript would not suffer because of it.
>>

I believe that the decay of the "wh" or "hw" sound if you prefer has 
been taking place for over a century or maybe two.  It is not easy to 
hear the difference in speech unless one happens to be listening 
closely.  I believe those whose job it is to do so have mapped where the 
sound is still used in the U.S. and where it isn't.  My understanding is 
that approximately 20% of the population still uses the sound.  I 
suspect younger speakers may be more likely to ignore the sound.

For those who have never used it, it seems superfluous as you indicate. 
 However, for those of us who do use it, deleting it from QS, would make 
the alphabet less accurate in its transcription of our speech.  We would 
resent that as much as anyone else would if someone suggested the 
deletion of a phoneme which they happen to be fond of because it appears

longer use  the "awe" sound, this would annoy many people across the 
country.  Nevertheless, I believe Canadians are quite content to avoid 
its use altogether.  An example: "cot" and "caught" are pronounced the 
same.  Sure seems peculiar to me, but it doesn't keep me from 
understanding them.

I counsel not throwing symbols out just because you don't happen to use

I have no problem with the inclusion of the "ch" as in Scottish "loch"

One last point:  if I write with the "wh" sound, you will notice it and

could hear his accent in his writing.  And it didn't keep me from

Paige Gabhart
